column6: Programs for upgrading employee skills and transition assistance programs
column13: for the second year, IGO was a Visionary Investor of the Future Female Leaders program curated for young females in year 11 from across metropolitan and regional Western Australia who are leading the way for future generations. In its first year, IGO had one mentor and has expanded this to six mentors who share their experiences and expertise with these young leaders.\t
column20: Future Female Leaders Program, Mentorship Expansion, Youth Leadership

column6: Programs for upgrading employee skills and transition assistance programs
column13: We are proud to offer our employees a compelling value proposition that provides benefits supporting our people and their families. We regularly review these benefits to ensure we continue attracting and retaining the best people and recruiting a diverse workforce.\t
column20: Employee Benefits, Value Proposition, Diversity Recruitment

column6: Programs for upgrading employee skills and transition assistance programs
column13: We regularly review our recruitment processes and work with hiring managers to attract and employ from a diverse candidate pool. It includes training hiring managers in unconscious bias and equal employment opportunities to ensure their teams are varied and balanced.\t

column6: Programs for upgrading employee skills and transition assistance programs
column13: In 2022, IGO became a Circle Back Initiative Employer, which means we are committed to responding to everyone applying for a position with us. We understand and appreciate the significant amount of time and energy that candidates invest into their application, and we want to continue to make a difference by providing a respectful candidate experience that counts. This initiative aligns strongly with our values and culture of care, and we are proud to drive change through fairer and kinder ways to treat candidates.

column6: Programs for upgrading employee skills and transition assistance programs
column13: We recognise that our existing employees can also be essential in attracting talented candidates to join our teams. Our people have significant professional networks across a range of sectors. They are well-placed to recommend potential candidates with the right skills and cultural fit for IGO and promote IGO as a great workplace. We offer a referral incentive to reward this effort after a successful candidate is recruited following their recommendation.\t
column20: Employee Referral Program, Talent Attraction, Referral Incentive

column6: Programs for upgrading employee skills and transition assistance programs
column8: Australian Association of Graduate Employers (AAGE) Top Intern Programs for 2023
column13: The Top Intern Programs list was created from a survey of over 1,800 undergraduate students who were part of their employer's intern program in 2022/2023. It aims to help students gain a deeper insight into the organisations that offer the best work experience programs. The IGO Vacation Program was the second highest-ranked mining company and was 27 out of 50 in Australia's overall list of programs.\t
column20: Top Intern Programs, Work Experience, Vacation Program

column6: Percentage of employees receiving regular performance and career development reviews
Diversity of governance bodies and employees
column7: Female representation of the total workforce is 27%. Female representation in IGO senior executive is 75%, and Females represented by IGO Board is 57%\t

column6: Diversity of governance bodies and employees
column13: IGO has been focused on transparency in how we approach pay equity for several years. We communicate this information to our people via our remuneration and reward standards and our short-term and long-term incentive programs that we make easily available to everyone. We regularly monitor and benchmark roles and gender to ensure we pay fair and equitable remuneration for all roles across our organisation.\t

column6: Ratio of basic salary and remuneration of women to men
column7: At the executive and management level, females were 0.95 and males 1.00; at the non-management level, females were 0.88 and males 1.00\t

column6: Incidents of discrimination and corrective actions taken
column7: In FY23, there were no material breaches of the Code of Conduct, Anti-Bribery and Corruption Standard or our Fraud controls.\t

column6: Incidents of discrimination and corrective actions taken
column13: IGO is committed to upholding the fundamental human rights of everyone with whom we engage in business. We aspire to be a business that recognises and respects the rights and dignity of all people by putting in place policies and procedures that aim to stamp out unethical practices within our global supply chains and by ensuring all our people are free to operate in an inclusive environment regardless of gender, marital status, race, impairment, religion, political beliefs or social preference. Our human rights approach aligns with Australia's national and international human rights obligations.\t

column4: Freedom of Association and Collective Bargaining
column6: Operations and suppliers in which the right to freedom of association and collective bargaining may be at risk
column7: IGO recognise our people's fundamental right to negotiate conditions of employment either individually or collectively. Reflecting our continued efforts to establish a culture of inclusion and positive relationships with our workforce, no time was lost due to industrial issues involving an IGO employee during FY23.\t

column7: In FY23, there were no material breaches of the Code of Conduct, Anti-Bribery and Corruption Standard or our Fraud controls.\t

column6: Operations that have been subject to human rights reviews or impacts assessments
column7: Our Modern Slavery Statement includes our approach to human rights reviews and assessments.\t

column6: Operations that have been subject to human rights reviews or impacts assessments
column13: Continuing our Custodians of Culture learning series has also been important for supervisors, providing them with the information and tools to create and support a positive and fair culture within their teams. Similarly, our respect in the Workplace course provides an understanding of bullying and harassment matters and a consistent set of behaviours and structure for all employees.\t

column6: Operations that have been subject to human rights reviews or impacts assessments
column13: In FY23, IGO established a Psychosocial Harms Working Group, which included an examination of sexual assault and sexual harassment as a significant component of its remit. This group has developed a plan to review and develop strategies to mitigate the risk of psychosocial harm and sexual harassment.\t

column6: Operations that have been subject to human rights reviews or impacts assessments
column8: Annual IGO Making a Difference Awards
column13: One of the significant annual programs to support, recognise and celebrate positive behaviours across the business is the yearly IGO Making a Difference Awards. This annual program recognises and honours those in our industry who have made an exceptional contribution to our business and who do this in a way consistent with our culture and values.\t

column6: Employee training on human rights policies or procedures
column7: All employees receive Corporate Governance training during the Company induction, which covers the IGO Human Rights Policy.\t

column6: Employee training on human rights policies or procedures
column13: Through our annual Engagement Survey, our people tell us they feel comfortable speaking up about safety and behavioural issues and are confident that our leaders will take the appropriate action when they do. In FY23, we continued to support our people with the Company-wide Speak Up online disclosure platform, which provides our people with an opportunity to raise concerns about actual or suspected misconduct via online submission.\t

column6: Employee training on human rights policies or procedures
column13: IGO is committed to preventing sexual harassment. The continuation of an immersive Sexual Harassment training program, which has now been embedded at all IGO locations, continues to educate individuals across the business about sexual harassment and behaviours that foster tremendous respect.\t

column6: Significant investment agreements and contracts that include human rights clauses or that underwent human rights screening
column7: We aspire to be a business that recognises and respects the rights and dignity of all people by putting in place policies and procedures that aim to stamp out unethical practices within our global supply chains and by ensuring all our people are free to operate in an inclusive environment regardless of gender, marital status, race, impairment, religion, political beliefs or social preference. Our human rights approach aligns with Australia's national and international human rights obligations. We express our respect for human rights in our Code of Conduct and reflect this in our purpose and values.\t

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column7: IGO actively pursues direct and respectful relationships through agreement-making and always strives to be a valued partner where we have an existing operation or exploration presence. IGO greatly values and appreciates the trust Traditional Owners place in IGO, and we will respect and do the right thing when operating in the country.\t

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column8: Support local communities and host governments
column13: IGO continues to support the local communities and host governments in which our operations are located, and our goal is to leave host communities in a better economic and social position than when we arrived. Acting ethically, responsibly and transparently is fundamental to how we conduct our business by our values.

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: We seek to invest first locally to support the economic development in the communities in which we operate. It is followed by regional investment within Western Australia, then nationally and finally internationally.\t
column20: Local investment, Economic development, Regional engagement

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column8: Supporting Local and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Businesses
column13: We support and favour businesses close to our operating areas and actively seek to engage and build capacity where suitable works are available. Providing opportunities for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander businesses is essential to IGO, and we will deliberately and specifically seek to identify contract works that might be suitable for local Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander corporations.\t
column20: Aboriginal businesses, Capacity building, Indigenous employment

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: Increasing employment opportunities for the Traditional Owners connected to the land near our Nova Operation through the Ngadju Employment Traineeship Program. The program offers a range of traineeship opportunities to gain experience across the exploration and mining cycle. It empowers trainees to choose their path through formal studies, mentoring and buddy programs, regular team-building activities and the flexibility to rotate across multiple roles. \t
column20: Ngadju Employment Traineeship Program, Traditional Owners, Empowerment

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: Our approach is guided by our Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Employment and Business Standards to drive the creation of Aboriginal employment opportunities across our business. Where applicable, IGO works with the relevant representative bodies to establish processes to support businesses owned and operated by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples.\t

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: IGO has also progressed negotiations for a comprehensive exploration and mining agreement with the Tjiwarl native title holders about our Cosmos Project and an exploration and mining agreement with Traditional Owners for the Raptor Project in the Northern Territory.\t
column20: Native title agreements, Negotiations, Indigenous engagement
